<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 118, 379, 143]]<|/det|>
# Cambridge IGCSE™  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 170, 183, 187]]<|/det|>
## PHYSICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 194, 368, 210]]<|/det|>
Paper 2 Multiple Choice (Extended)  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[784, 170, 905, 187]]<|/det|>
0625/23  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[784, 194, 905, 210]]<|/det|>
May/June 2022  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[814, 217, 905, 232]]<|/det|>
45 minutes  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 247, 507, 263]]<|/det|>
You must answer on the multiple choice answer sheet.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 277, 437, 293]]<|/det|>
You will need: Multiple choice answer sheet  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[215, 291, 539, 320]]<|/det|>
Soft clean eraser Soft pencil (type B or HB is recommended)  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 336, 228, 352]]<|/det|>
## INSTRUCTIONS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 353, 880, 522]]<|/det|>
INSTRUCTIONS- There are forty questions on this paper. Answer all questions.- For each question there are four possible answers A, B, C and D. Choose the one you consider correct and record your choice in soft pencil on the multiple choice answer sheet.- Follow the instructions on the multiple choice answer sheet.- Write in soft pencil.- Write your name, centre number and candidate number on the multiple choice answer sheet in the spaces provided unless this has been done for you.- Do not use correction fluid.- Do not write on any bar codes.- You may use a calculator.- Take the weight of \(1.0 \text{kg}\) to be \(10 \text{N}\) (acceleration of free fall \(= 10 \text{m/s}^2\)).  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 549, 220, 564]]<|/det|>
## INFORMATION  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 565, 570, 612]]<|/det|>
INFORMATION- The total mark for this paper is 40.- Each correct answer will score one mark.- Any rough working should be done on this question paper.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[268, 847, 728, 864]]<|/det|>
This document has 20 pages. Any blank pages are indicated.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 694, 695, 712]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 720, 631, 739]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 106, 88]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 920, 104]]<|/det|> The diagram shows gas particles hitting the wall of a container. The system is at room temperature. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[373, 114, 621, 233]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 244, 566, 263]]<|/det|> Why do the gas particles exert a pressure on the wall? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 272, 134, 291]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 272, 809, 291]]<|/det|> When the particles hit the wall, their momentum changes, which causes a force. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 300, 133, 317]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 300, 729, 317]]<|/det|> When the particles hit the wall, their average kinetic energy increases. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 326, 134, 344]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 326, 510, 344]]<|/det|> The particles expand when they hit the wall. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 352, 133, 370]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 352, 455, 370]]<|/det|> The particles collide with each other. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 395, 104, 414]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 395, 722, 413]]<|/det|> A gas in a container is cooled but the volume of the gas does not change. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 425, 920, 459]]<|/det|> Which row describes the changes in the pressure of the gas and the kinetic energy of the gas particles? <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 470, 536, 617]]<|/det|>
pressure of gaskinetic energy of gas particles
Adecreasesdecreases
Bdecreasesincreases
Cincreasesdecreases
Dincreasesincreases

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 72, 106, 88]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 690, 89]]<|/det|> The iron cylinder of an engine is to be fitted into a piece of aluminium. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 102, 920, 135]]<|/det|> The outside diameter \(M\) of the iron cylinder is slightly larger than the diameter \(N\) of the hole in the aluminium. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[361, 141, 635, 371]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 380, 613, 399]]<|/det|> What is the best action to fit the cylinder into the aluminium? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 409, 134, 428]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 409, 462, 428]]<|/det|> Cool the aluminium and cool the iron. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 437, 134, 455]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 437, 462, 455]]<|/det|> Cool the aluminium and heat the iron. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 463, 134, 482]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 463, 462, 481]]<|/det|> Heat the aluminium and cool the iron. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 489, 134, 507]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 489, 465, 507]]<|/det|> Heat the aluminium and heat the iron. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 533, 106, 551]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 533, 870, 551]]<|/det|> Four metal blocks at a temperature of \(200^{\circ}\mathrm{C}\) are left to cool down to the same temperature. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 562, 917, 581]]<|/det|> The table gives the mass of each block and the energy it transfers to the surroundings as it cools. <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[304, 592, 693, 720]]<|/det|>
blockmass/genergy transferred/J
110016 200
215016 200
320032 400
42008 100

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 106, 88]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 698, 89]]<|/det|> The circuit shown consists of a vertical wire, a resistor R and a battery. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 102, 504, 119]]<|/det|> The magnetic field near the wire is also shown. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 128, 878, 298]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 317, 425, 335]]<|/det|> Two changes are made to the circuit: <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[186, 348, 539, 365]]<|/det|> · The polarity of the battery is reversed. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[186, 373, 868, 390]]<|/det|> · The resistor R is replaced with another resistor with a lower resistance than R. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 403, 714, 420]]<|/det|> What effect will these changes have on the magnetic field near the wire? <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 432, 507, 579]]<|/det|>
direction of magnetic fieldstrength of magnetic field

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 605, 106, 623]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 605, 720, 623]]<|/det|> Carbon-14 has a proton number (Z) of 6 and a nucleon number (A) of 14. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 636, 670, 653]]<|/det|> Nitrogen-14 has a proton number of 7 and a nucleon number of 14. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 667, 514, 684]]<|/det|> Carbon-14 emits \(\beta\) -particles to form nitrogen-14. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 698, 512, 714]]<|/det|> Which nuclide equation describes this process? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 728, 133, 746]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 728, 292, 746]]<|/det|> \(^{14}_{6}\mathrm {C}\rightarrow ^{14}_{7}\mathrm {N}+\ ^{0}_{1}\beta\) <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 761, 133, 778]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 761, 292, 778]]<|/det|> \(^{14}_{6}\mathrm {C}\rightarrow ^{14}_{7}\mathrm {N}+\ ^{1}_{0}\beta\) <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 792, 133, 810]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 792, 298, 810]]<|/det|> \(^{14}_{6}\mathrm {C}\rightarrow ^{14}_{7}\mathrm {N}+\ ^{0}_{-1}\beta\) <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 825, 133, 843]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 825, 298, 843]]<|/det|> \(^{14}_{6}\mathrm {C}\rightarrow ^{14}_{7}\mathrm {N}+\ ^{1}_{0}\beta\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 106, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>39</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 72, 920, 107]]<|/det|>
A beam of radiation, containing \(\alpha\) -particles, \(\beta\) -particles and \(\gamma\) -rays, passes between two parallel plates. One plate is positively charged and the other is negatively charged.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 116, 798, 136]]<|/det|>
Which radioactive emissions will be attracted towards the positively charged plate?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 147, 138, 165]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 147, 282, 165]]<|/det|>
\(\alpha\) -particles only

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 175, 133, 193]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 175, 280, 193]]<|/det|>
\(\beta\) -particles only

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 202, 133, 220]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 202, 245, 220]]<|/det|>
\(\gamma\) -rays only

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 228, 133, 247]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 228, 428, 247]]<|/det|>
\(\alpha\) -particles, \(\beta\) -particles and \(\gamma\) -rays

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 272, 104, 291]]<|/det|>
<label>40</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 272, 787, 291]]<|/det|>
A scientist uses a counter to measure the radioactivity of a sample of nitrogen-13.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 303, 685, 320]]<|/det|>
The counter and sample of nitrogen-13 are on a table in a laboratory.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 333, 920, 367]]<|/det|>
The reading on the counter is recorded for a period of \(80\mathrm{min}\) and a graph is drawn using the measurements.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[81, 376, 915, 682]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 694, 697, 712]]<|/det|>
What is the best estimate for the half-life of the sample of nitrogen-13?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 723, 134, 740]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 723, 208, 740]]<|/det|>
10 min

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[280, 723, 303, 740]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[318, 723, 376, 740]]<|/det|>
12 min

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[448, 723, 470, 740]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[480, 723, 544, 740]]<|/det|>
14 min

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[615, 723, 636, 740]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[650, 723, 710, 740]]<|/det|>
40 min
